üéØ


Course Description


This introductory course covers the foundations of statistical thinking, including data description, probability, and inference. Students will learn how to summarize data, compute basic probabilities, and make informed decisions using statistical tools.

Student Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Summarize data using descriptive statistics
Understand fundamental probability rules and distributions
Conduct basic inferential procedures (confidence intervals, hypothesis tests)
Interpret results and communicate findings

title: PSTAT 5A Lab 1
text:
Welcome to the first PSTAT 5A Lab! As we will soon learn, computers play an integral part in effectively and efficiently performing statistical analyses. The primary goal of these Labs is to develop the skills to communicate with computers and learn the basic principles and language of programming.
This first lab will introduce you to the JupyterHub environment, Python as a programming language, and some basic concepts of programming. You will also complete a series of tasks to familiarize yourself with the tools and concepts we will use throughout the course.
This lab is designed to be completed during your first lab section of the week, and it will set the foundation for the rest of the course. Make sure to read through all the material carefully, as it will be essential for your success in PSTAT 5A.



Every week we (the course staff) will publish a lab document, which is intended to be completed during your Lab Section (i.e., your first Section) of the week. Each lab document will consist of a combination of text, tips, and the occasional task for you to complete based on the text provided. Your TA will cover exactly what you need to turn in at the end of each lab in order to receive credit, but you should read all lab material carefully and thoroughly as content from labs will appear on quizzes and exams.




Computers, though incredibly useful, are fairly complex machines. To communicate with them, we need to use a specific language, known as a programming language. There are a number of programming languages currently in use‚ÄîR, Julia, MatLab, and the language we will use for this course, Python.
Python programs can be written in many environments (e.g., text editors like VS Code or in a Terminal window). For this class we will use Jupyter Notebook (pronounced ‚ÄúJew-pi-ter‚Äù), an interactive environment that‚Äôs hosted online so you don‚Äôt have to install anything to run Python code!





Navigate to (https://pstat5a.lsit.ucsb.edu)

If you are using a personal computer, you may want to bookmark this page for easy access later.

Click Sign in with your UCSB NetID, and sign in.

Navigate to the Labs folder on the left-hand side of the JupyterHub interface. 
Under Notebook, click Python 3 (ipykernel).


Congratulations, you have just made your first Jupyter notebook! Now, it‚Äôs time for our first task:





Find your new notebook in the left-hand file browser (it will be named Untitled or Untitled1 by default).

Right-click the notebook and select ‚Üí Rename.

Rename it to Lab1 and hit Enter.

Watch the title bar update to Lab1.ipynb.





Jupyter notebooks are built from cells‚Äîthe shaded boxes you see on screen. Here‚Äôs how to work with them:



Inactive cell

Appearance: light grey background

Action: click anywhere inside the cell to activate


Active cell

Appearance: colored border (green or blue)

You can now type code or Markdown here.



Tip: Only the active cell runs when you press Run.





Click the ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run button in the toolbar

Or press Shift + Enter to run and advance to the next cell







You can switch any cell between Code and Markdown:



Purpose: write and execute Python code

Select:

Click the cell

Choose Code from the toolbar dropdown



Run: ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run button or Shift + Enter





Purpose: write formatted text, headings, lists, math, and embed images

Select:

Click the cell

Choose Markdown from the toolbar dropdown


Render: ‚ñ∂Ô∏è Run button or Shift + Enter






Click into the initial cell ( marked by [ ] on the left).

In the toolbar dropdown (that currently says Code), select Markdown.

Copy-paste the following (including the #):
# Task 2
Run the cell (‚ñ∂Ô∏è).
Create a new code cell by clicking the + button in the toolbar.


Alternatively, you can press B to add a cell below the current one or A to add one above it.

This option preserves the previous cell type (Code or Markdown).

You can also right-click the cell and select Insert Cell Below or Insert Cell Above.
You can also use the Insert menu at the top of the page. > Tip: Press Shift + Enter to run a cell and move to (or create) the next one.

Enter and run:
2 + 2
Observe that a new cell appears under it automatically.


Tip: Press Shift + Enter to run a cell and move to (or create) the next one.





Create a new Markdown cell labeled:
# Task 3
Create a new code cell and run:
2 plus 2
Observe the SyntaxError and note how Python points to the problem.


Note: Always read error messages, they tell you what went wrong!





Python follows the usual order of operations:

Parentheses

Exponents

Multiplication / Division

Addition / Subtraction




Operation
Python Syntax
Example
Result




Addition
+
2 + 2
4


Subtraction
-
2 - 2
0


Multiplication
*
2 * 2
4


Division
/
2 / 2
1.0


Exponentiation
**
2 ** 2
4






Compute the following in separate code cells:

\[\frac{2 + 3}{4 + 5^6}\]
\[(1 - 3 \cdot 4^5)^6\]





In Python, a module is simply a file (with a .py extension) that contains related code, functions, classes, and variables‚Äîthat you can reuse in other programs. Modules help you organize your code, avoid naming conflicts, and leverage functionality written by others.



Reusability: Write a function once, then import it wherever you need it.

Organization: Group related functionality into logical units (e.g., math operations).

Namespace Management: Keep your global namespace clean by accessing code through the module‚Äôs name.




There are several ways to bring module code into your current script or notebook:

Import the entire module
import math
print(math.sin(1))
Import specific names
from math import sin, pi
print(sin(pi/2))
Import with an alias
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])


Tip: Use specific imports (from module import name) to keep your namespace tidy, or aliases (import module as m) for brevity.






Standard library: Modules like math, random, and datetime come with Python.

Third-party: Install via pip install package_name (e.g.¬†pip install pandas).

Your own: Create my_utils.py and then import my_utils in your project.

Modules are the building blocks of larger Python applications; get comfortable importing and exploring them!






In a code cell, type:
sin(1)
Observe the NameError.

In the same (or a new) cell, load the module and retry:
from math import *
sin(1)





Variables in Python are used to store data values. You can think of them as labels for data that you want to use later in your program.

Assignment:
x = 2
Printing:
print(x)

Python is case-sensitive: my_variable ‚â† My_variable.

Behind the scenes, print() is a function that takes one or more values and displays them on the screen. We‚Äôll learn what functions are and how to create our own functions soon.






Assign:
my_variable = 5
In a new cell, run:
print(My_variable)
‚Äì observe the NameError due to wrong capitalization.
NameError: name 'My_variable' is not defined
In the same cell, run:
print(my_variable)
Now you should see 5 printed without any errors.





Comments are notes in your code that Python ignores when running the program. They help you and others understand what your code does. Comments are essential for documenting your code, explaining complex logic, or leaving reminders for yourself or others. They do not affect the execution of your program.
You can add comments anywhere in your code, and they can be on their own line or at the end of a line of code.
In Python, comments start with a # symbol. Everything after the # on that line is considered a comment and will not be executed by Python. You can also use multi-line comments with triple quotes (""" or '''), which allows you to write longer explanations or block comments that span multiple lines. These are often used for documentation strings (docstrings) to describe functions, classes, or modules.
You can add comments in two ways:

Inline comment: Use # to comment out a single line.
Example:
# This is an inline comment
x = 5  # Assign 5 to x
Block comment: Use triple quotes """ or ''' to comment out multiple lines.

Example:
"""
Multiple lines
of comment here
"""





Go back and add descriptive comments to some of your previous code cells.




Python has several basic data types, which are the building blocks for more complex data structures. The most common ones are: - bool ‚Äî boolean (e.g.¬†True, False)

NoneType ‚Äî represents the absence of a value (e.g.¬†None)
list ‚Äî ordered collection (e.g.¬†[1, 2, 3])
tuple ‚Äî immutable ordered collection (e.g.¬†(1, 2, 3))
dict ‚Äî key-value pairs (e.g.¬†`{‚Äúkey‚Äù: ‚Äúvalue‚Äù})
set ‚Äî unordered collection of unique items (e.g.¬†{1, 2, 3})

The most basic data types you will use in this course are:

int ‚Äî integer (e.g.¬†1, 42)
float ‚Äî real number (e.g.¬†1.0, 3.14)

str ‚Äî string/text (e.g.¬†"hello", 'abc')





Run each in its own cell:
type(1)
type(1.1)
type("hello")




You can assign values to variables and use them in expressions. Here‚Äôs an example:





Create a new Markdown cell labeled:
# Task 9
In a new code cell, perform the following variable assignments:
course = "PSTAT 5A"
num_sections = 4
section_capacity = 25
A new section has been added! Update the variable num_sections to be one more than when you initially defined it above. (Don‚Äôt just use num_sections = 5- think about our discussion on updating variables above!)
Using comments, write down what you think the output of each of the following expressions will be:
type(course)
type(num_sections)
num_sections * section_capacity
Then, run each expression in a separate code chunk and comment on the results.
Create a new variable called course_capacity and assign it the value of the maximum capacity of the course. (Hint: there are only 5 sections, and each section has a maximum capacity of 25. Try to use your already-defined variables as much as possible!)





That wraps up Lab 1! You‚Äôve successfully navigated the JupyterHub environment, learned how to switch between and run Code and Markdown cells, experimented with basic Python expressions, and practiced variable assignment. In Lab 2, we‚Äôll dive deeper into Python functions, data structures, and more advanced programming concepts. Great work, see you next time!






üîñ Table of Contents
- PSTAT 5A Lab 1  - Structure of Labs  - What Is Programming?  - Getting Started  - Task 1  - The JupyterHub Environment  - 1. Cell Activation  - 2. Running Cells  - Cell Types  - Code Cells  - Markdown Cells  - Task 2  - Task 3  - Python as a Calculator  - Task 4  - Python Modules  - Why Use Modules?  - Importing Modules  - Finding and Installing Modules  - Task 5  - Variable Assignment  - Task 6  - Comments  - Task 7  - Basic Data Types  - Task 8  - Using Variables and Data Types  - Task 9  - Conclusion

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
What are Descriptive Statistics?

Descriptive statistics are numerical and graphical methods used to summarize, organize, and describe data in a meaningful way.

Purpose of Descriptive Statistics

Summarize large datasets into manageable information
Identify patterns and trends in data
Communicate findings clearly to others
Prepare data for further analysis
Make initial assessments about data quality

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Statistics

Facts are stubborn, but statistics are more pliable.
Mark Twain

Statistics refers to the mathematics and techniques with which we understand data. 1



(source)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Descriptive vs.¬†Inferential Statistics







Descriptive Statistics
Inferential Statistics




Describes what the data shows
Makes predictions about populations


Summarizes sample data
Uses sample data to make generalizations


No conclusions beyond the data
Draws conclusions beyond the immediate data


Examples: mean, median, graphs
Examples: hypothesis testing, confidence intervals

text: Descriptive vs.¬†Inferential Statistics

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Why Data Types Matter
Understanding data types is crucial because:


Different statistics are appropriate for different data types
Statistical methods depend on the level of measurement
Misapplying statistics can lead to incorrect conclusions

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Categorical Data (Qualitative)


Nominal Data

Categories with no natural order
Examples: gender, color, brand names, marital status
Appropriate statistics: mode, frequency counts, proportions


Ordinal Data

Categories with a natural order or ranking
Examples: education level, satisfaction ratings, letter grades
Appropriate statistics: mode, median, percentiles

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Numerical Data (Quantitative)

Discrete Data

Countable values, often integers
Examples: number of children, cars sold, defective items
Can take on finite or countably infinite values



Continuous Data

Can take any value within a range
Examples: height, weight, temperature, time
Measured rather than counted

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
What is Central Tendency?
Central tendency describes the center or typical value of a dataset.
It answers the question: ‚ÄúWhat is a representative value for this data?‚Äù

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Definition and Formula
The mean is the sum of all values divided by the number of values.

Formula

For a sample: \(\bar{x} = \frac{\sum x}{n}\)
For a population: \(\mu = \frac{\sum x}{N}\)

Where:

\(\bar{x}\) (x-bar) = sample mean
\(\mu\) (mu) = population mean
\(\sum x\) = sum of all values
\(n\) = sample size, \(N\) = population size

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Example Calculation
Student test scores: 85, 90, 78, 92, 88

Mean = \(\frac{85 + 90 + 78 + 92 + 88}{5} = \frac{433}{5} = 86.6\)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Properties of the Mean

Uses all data points - every value affects the mean
Sensitive to outliers - extreme values can distort the mean
Unique - there is only one mean for a dataset
Can be calculated for interval and ratio data
Balancing point - sum of deviations from mean equals zero

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
When to Use the Mean
‚úÖ Use the mean when:

Data is approximately symmetric
No extreme outliers present
Working with interval or ratio data
Need to use the value in further calculations

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Advantages and Disadvantages


Advantages

Uses all information in the dataset
Algebraically defined and mathematically tractable
Widely understood and accepted


Disadvantages

Affected by outliers and skewed distributions
May not represent a typical value in skewed data
Cannot be used with nominal or ordinal data

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Definition
The median is the middle value when data is arranged in ascending or descending order.

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Calculation Steps

Arrange data in ascending order
Find the middle position:

If n is odd: position = \(\frac{n + 1}{2}\)
If n is even: average of positions \(\frac{n}{2}\) and \(\frac{n}{2} + 1\)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Examples

Odd number of values:


Data: 12, 15, 18, 20, 25
What is the median here ?
Median = 18 (middle value)




Even number of values:


Data: 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35
What is the median here ?
Median = \(\frac{20 + 25}{2} = 22.5\)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Properties of the Median


Not affected by outliers - resistant measure
Represents the 50th percentile
May not be an actual data value (when n is even)
Appropriate for ordinal, interval, and ratio data
Divides data into two equal halves

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
When to Use the Median
‚úÖ Use the median when:

Data is skewed (not symmetric)
Outliers are present
Working with ordinal data
Want a robust measure of central tendency
Data represents income, housing prices, or similar distributions

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Median vs Mean with Outliers
Consider household incomes: $30,000, $32,000, $35,000, $38,000, $2,000,000


Mean = $427,000 (not representative of typical household)
Median = $35,000 (better represents typical household)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Definition
The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset.

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Types of Distributions by Mode

Unimodal: One mode
Bimodal: Two modes

Multimodal: More than two modes
No mode: All values appear with equal frequency

Properties of the Mode

Can be used with any type of data (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio)
Not affected by outliers
May not exist or may not be unique
Represents the most common value
Easy to identify in frequency distributions

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
When to Use the Mode
‚úÖ Use the mode when:

Working with categorical (nominal) data
Want to identify the most popular or common choice
Data has clear peaks in frequency
Quality control applications (most common defect type)
Business applications (best-selling product, most common customer complaint)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Shape of Distribution Effects

Symmetric distribution: Mean ‚âà Median ‚âà Mode
Right-skewed (positively skewed): Mean > Median > Mode

Left-skewed (negatively skewed): Mode > Median > Mean

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Essential Libraries

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from scipy import stats
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Calculating the Mean

# Sample data
data = [85, 90, 78, 92, 88]

# Using NumPy
mean_np = np.mean(data)
print(f"Mean (NumPy): {mean_np}")

# Using Pandas
df = pd.DataFrame({'scores': data})
mean_pd = df['scores'].mean()
print(f"Mean (Pandas): {mean_pd}")

Output:
Mean (NumPy): 86.6
Mean (Pandas): 86.6

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Calculating the Median

# Using NumPy
median_np = np.median(data)
print(f"Median (NumPy): {median_np}")

# Using Pandas
median_pd = df['scores'].median()
print(f"Median (Pandas): {median_pd}")

Output:
Median (NumPy): 88.0
Median (Pandas): 88.0

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Calculating the Mode

# Using SciPy
from scipy import stats
mode_result = stats.mode(data)
print(f"Mode: {mode_result.mode}, Count: {mode_result.count}")

# Using Pandas
mode_pd = df['scores'].mode()
print(f"Mode (Pandas): {mode_pd.values}")

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Comprehensive Analysis Function

def descriptive_summary(data, column_name="Data"):
    """Calculate comprehensive descriptive statistics"""
    df = pd.DataFrame({column_name: data})
    
    print(f"Descriptive Statistics for {column_name}")
    print("=" * 40)
    print(f"Count: {len(data)}")
    print(f"Mean: {np.mean(data):.2f}")
    print(f"Median: {np.median(data):.2f}")
    
    try:
        mode_result = stats.mode(data)
        print(f"Mode: {mode_result.mode[0]} (appears {mode_result.count[0]} times)")
    except:
        print("Mode: No unique mode")
    
    return df.describe()

# Example usage
test_scores = [85, 90, 78, 92, 88, 91, 85, 87, 89, 86]
summary = descriptive_summary(test_scores, "Test Scores")

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Handling Categorical Data

# Categorical data example
categories = ['A', 'B', 'B', 'C', 'A', 'B', 'A', 'C', 'B', 'B']
cat_series = pd.Series(categories)

print("Categorical Data Analysis:")
print(f"Mode: {cat_series.mode().values[0]}")
print("\nValue Counts:")
print(cat_series.value_counts())

Output:
Categorical Data Analysis:
Mode: B

Value Counts:
B    5
A    3
C    2

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Business Applications

Customer Satisfaction: Mean rating shows overall satisfaction, median shows typical experience
Sales Data: Mode identifies best-selling products, median shows typical sale amount

Employee Performance: Mean for overall team performance, median for typical employee

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Educational Applications

Test Scores: Mean for class average, median for typical student performance
Grade Distribution: Mode shows most common grade
Attendance: Mean for overall attendance rate

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Healthcare Applications

Patient Wait Times: Median often preferred due to skewed distributions
Treatment Outcomes: Mean for overall effectiveness, mode for most common result
Vital Signs: All three measures provide different insights

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Interpretation Guidelines

Always consider the context of your data
Report multiple measures when appropriate

Be aware of data distribution shape
Consider the presence of outliers
Choose the most appropriate measure for your specific question

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I
text:
Remember These Points

Data type determines which statistics are appropriate
Mean uses all data but is sensitive to outliers
Median is robust and represents the middle value
Mode identifies the most common value and works with all data types
Context matters when choosing and interpreting measures
Python provides powerful tools for calculating descriptive statistics

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Learning Objectives (LOs)
By the end of this lecture you should be able to:

Define descriptive statistics and explain its importance in data analysis (Section¬†1)
Distinguish between different types of data and measurement scales (Section¬†2)
Calculate and interpret measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode)(Section¬†3)
Understand when to use each measure of central tendency
Apply Python to compute descriptive statistics(Section¬†9)
Interpret basic descriptive statistics in real-world contexts(Section¬†10)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Statistics

Facts are stubborn, but statistics are more pliable.
Mark Twain

Statistics refers to the mathematics and techniques with which we understand data. 1

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
What are Descriptive Statistics?

Descriptive statistics are numerical and graphical methods used to summarize, organize, and describe data in a meaningful way.


Purpose of Descriptive Statistics

Summarize large datasets into manageable information
Identify patterns and trends in data
Communicate findings clearly to others
Prepare data for further analysis
Make initial assessments about data quality

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Descriptive vs.¬†Inferential Statistics







Descriptive Statistics
Inferential Statistics




Describes what the data shows
Makes predictions about populations


Summarizes sample data
Uses sample data to make generalizations


No conclusions beyond the data
Draws conclusions beyond the immediate data


Examples: mean, median, graphs
Examples: hypothesis testing, confidence intervals

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text: Descriptive vs.¬†Inferential Statistics

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Why Data Types Matter
Understanding data types is crucial because:


Different statistics are appropriate for different data types
Statistical methods depend on the level of measurement
Misapplying statistics can lead to incorrect conclusions

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Categorical Data (Qualitative)



Nominal Data

Categories with no natural order
Examples: gender, color, brand names, marital status
Appropriate statistics: mode, frequency counts, proportions




Ordinal Data

Categories with a natural order or ranking
Examples: education level, satisfaction ratings, letter grades
Appropriate statistics: mode, median, percentiles

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Numerical Data (Quantitative)


Discrete Data

Countable values, often integers
Examples: number of children, cars sold, defective items
Can take on finite or countably infinite values





Continuous Data

Can take any value within a range
Examples: height, weight, temperature, time
Measured rather than counted

Definition
The mode is the value that appears most frequently in a dataset.

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Example 1:
Data: 2, 3, 3, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 7

Analysis:


Count each value: 2(1), 3(2), 4(1), 5(3), 6(1), 7(1)
Most frequent value: 5 appears 3 times
Mode = 5
Type: Unimodal (one mode)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Example 2:
Data: 1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 5

Analysis:


Count each value: 1(1), 2(2), 3(1), 4(2), 5(1)
Most frequent values: 2 and 4 both appear twice
Modes = 2 and 4
Type: Bimodal (two modes)

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Example 3:
Data: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

Analysis:


Count each value: 1(1), 2(1), 3(1), 4(1), 5(1)
All values appear exactly once
No mode (no value repeats)
Type: No mode

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Mode for Different Data Types

Categorical Data:
Favorite colors: Red, Blue, Blue, Green, Blue, Red, Blue Mode = Blue


Continuous Data:
Often requires grouping into intervals or bins Example: Heights grouped into ranges

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Properties of the Mode

Can be used with any type of data (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio)
Not affected by outliers
May not exist or may not be unique
Represents the most common value
Easy to identify in frequency distributions

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
When to Use the Mode
‚úÖ Use the mode when:

Working with categorical (nominal) data
Want to identify the most popular or common choice
Data has clear peaks in frequency
Quality control applications (most common defect type)
Business applications (best-selling product, most common customer complaint)

text:

Measure

Weaknesses

Mean
Interval, Ratio
Uses all data, mathematically tractable
Sensitive to outliers
Yes


Median
Ordinal, Interval, Ratio
Robust to outliers, represents middle
Ignores extreme values
No

All types
Works with categorical, identifies most common
May not exist/be unique
No

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Shape of Distribution Effects

Symmetric distribution: Mean ‚âà Median ‚âà Mode
Right-skewed (positively skewed): Mean > Median > Mode

Left-skewed (negatively skewed): Mode > Median > Mean

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Essential Libraries

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from scipy import stats
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Calculating the Mean

# Sample data
data = [85, 90, 78, 92, 88]

# Using NumPy
mean_np = np.mean(data)
print(f"Mean (NumPy): {mean_np}")

# Using Pandas
df = pd.DataFrame({'scores': data})
mean_pd = df['scores'].mean()
print(f"Mean (Pandas): {mean_pd}")

Output:
Mean (NumPy): 86.6
Mean (Pandas): 86.6

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Calculating the Median

# Using NumPy
median_np = np.median(data)
print(f"Median (NumPy): {median_np}")

# Using Pandas
median_pd = df['scores'].median()
print(f"Median (Pandas): {median_pd}")

Output:
Median (NumPy): 88.0
Median (Pandas): 88.0

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Calculating the Mode

# Using SciPy
from scipy import stats
mode_result = stats.mode(data)
print(f"Mode: {mode_result.mode}, Count: {mode_result.count}")

# Using Pandas
mode_pd = df['scores'].mode()
print(f"Mode (Pandas): {mode_pd.values}")

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Comprehensive Analysis Function

def descriptive_summary(data, column_name="Data"):
    """Calculate comprehensive descriptive statistics"""
    df = pd.DataFrame({column_name: data})
    
    print(f"Descriptive Statistics for {column_name}")
    print("=" * 40)
    print(f"Count: {len(data)}")
    print(f"Mean: {np.mean(data):.2f}")
    print(f"Median: {np.median(data):.2f}")
    
    try:
        mode_result = stats.mode(data)
        print(f"Mode: {mode_result.mode[0]} (appears {mode_result.count[0]} times)")
    except:
        print("Mode: No unique mode")
    
    return df.describe()

# Example usage
test_scores = [85, 90, 78, 92, 88, 91, 85, 87, 89, 86]
summary = descriptive_summary(test_scores, "Test Scores")

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Handling Categorical Data

# Categorical data example
categories = ['A', 'B', 'B', 'C', 'A', 'B', 'A', 'C', 'B', 'B']
cat_series = pd.Series(categories)

print("Categorical Data Analysis:")
print(f"Mode: {cat_series.mode().values[0]}")
print("\nValue Counts:")
print(cat_series.value_counts())

Output:
Categorical Data Analysis:
Mode: B

Value Counts:
B    5
A    3
C    2

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Business Applications

Customer Satisfaction: Mean rating shows overall satisfaction, median shows typical experience
Sales Data: Mode identifies best-selling products, median shows typical sale amount

Employee Performance: Mean for overall team performance, median for typical employee

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Educational Applications

Test Scores: Mean for class average, median for typical student performance
Grade Distribution: Mode shows most common grade
Attendance: Mean for overall attendance rate

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Healthcare Applications

Patient Wait Times: Median often preferred due to skewed distributions
Treatment Outcomes: Mean for overall effectiveness, mode for most common result
Vital Signs: All three measures provide different insights

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Interpretation Guidelines

Always consider the context of your data
Report multiple measures when appropriate

Be aware of data distribution shape
Consider the presence of outliers
Choose the most appropriate measure for your specific question

title: Lecture 2: Descriptive Statistics I - Part II
text:
Remember These Points

Data type determines which statistics are appropriate
Mean uses all data but is sensitive to outliers
Median is robust and represents the middle value
Mode identifies the most common value and works with all data types
Context matters when choosing and interpreting measures
Python provides powerful tools for calculating descriptive statistics
